postcontent:
As you may know, Remington introduced the .244 in 1955 (the same year Winchester introduced the .243). Remington misread the market and introduced their .244 caliber with a 1:12 twist designed to stabilize light varmint bullets whereas Winchester introduced their .243 with a 1:9 twist which proved more suitable for stabilizing the larger dual purpose (deer/varmint) bullets. The .243 dominated the market but Remington quickly learned from their mistake and began rebarreling in a slower twist as of 1958. By then, however, the damage had been done and sales of the .244 continued to suffer. In 1963 they pulled the rifle and reintroduced it as the 6mm Remington and the rest is history. 
I expect that it will have extra value to collectors due to the chambering.  .244 Remington is the same as 6mm Remington.  Remington first called the caliber 6mm, but sales were poor.  They changed the name to .244 in hopes of improving sales, but it had the opposite effect.  The name was changed back to 6mm but never gained a good enough market for the caliber.

postcontent:
For Sale: Hammerli 208 S, with Morini Grip that has been modified very slightly on the R slab.  

Personally, I don't particularly favor the S models over the 208, but for those who want a two stage trigger or need the adjustable trigger shoe as on the 208S or 215S S, this is the last 208S under $3000 that I'll be releasing after testing and evaluation, for quite a while to come.

This is a special edition gun, with Hammerli in gold, and an unusually well polished finish for a 208 S (usually, these are rather matte or dull).  In that sense, it is NOT a typical 208S, but is equally funtional and equally accurate.  The RH side of the grip has been recut slightly, to improve the hand fit.  This is significantly better than the factory new Morini grip (which is not designed for a perfect fit, but for custom recutting).

The last image shows the left handed grip that can be provided with this gun if desired.  It is imaged on a different gun, but the fit is identical.  Price with this grip is $200 higher.

The gun also can be provided in "211" configuration with a 212 grip.

This gun is one of several target and "other use" pistols available, which are NOT listed on Armslist.  For a complete list and EXPERT'S SELECTION GUIDE to these guns, please email.  The guide and list are free.  The guide also lists some 208 that are available.  

The Morini grip (original to the gun) fits hand sizes up to about 8.7cm span, and a bit more.  An extra 0.7 cm of size can be added to that easily by additional cutting to the bottom shelf.  The Morini grips are designed for longer fingers than the OEM Hammerli grips, but this one has been recut for easier use with "typical" length fingers.

For those with Annie Oakley or Hobbitoid hands, an OEM Hammerli small grip is available, but does not have an adjustable lower shelf. 

FFL transfer only.

Additional magazines available, either extended or short base, 8 or 10 rd capacity.  However, the magazines are available only with purchase of a Hammerli 2xx series gun from me.  The 8 rd is required in some states, and is preferred for 5-shot competitions due to better feed.

Price includes an 80 gm weight. Price reduction with no weight. 200 and 240 gm weights also available, extra cost.  This is NOT a SigArms import, and does not have their upper section safety.

Hammerli-SIG P240 in all calibers incl 22lr, 208, and 212 also available, and other 208S. The other S models are basically similar to this one, except for one with gold Hammerli lettering, at higher price.

For those who have not used these are are just starting, the 208 and 208S parallel the S&W41 as a child of the Walther Olympia pistol and other derivative .22 guns. These, in their own way, likely are derivatives of the Reising Target pistol of the 1920s.

The 208 S offers a 2 stage trigger with a fair range of adjustments, including trigger position. The predecessor 208 uses a single stage trigger, with no significant adjustment for trigger position possible. Some internal changes for springing and adjustment also were made from the earlier 208 models, also incorporated in the 215 and later 208 models with wide trigger shoes.

In general, these guns are not as accurate as the SAKO TriAce and do not have the range of internal adjustment which that gun offers, but the clearances are not as tight, and they are less fussy or sensitive to ammunition. The 208 S has never "beaten" the scores of the 208 in competion, but has gained preference at this time over the 208 for many.

The barrel weight serves both to change the feel of the gun, and to serve as a precision barrel tuner, similar to the micrometer tuners used on some rifles. With a 240 gm weight, the feel of the gun "approximates" that of the GSP, but the grip of the 208 is similar to the S&W 41 or the Colt 1911. On the SIG 240, and GSP, it is sloped.

Scope or optical sight rails are available from a number of sources for this gun. Most of them also can be used on the 208, and a few on the 212 as well.

The gun accuracy is in the 0.15 MOA range (yes 0.15, not 1.5) with precise barrel weight tuning.  Without that but with optimized ammunition, accuracy is about 0.9 MOA.  For comparison, the best S&W41 generally are at about 1.2-1.4 MOA, but do not offer the adjustable trigger or ability to change the barrel weight easily.

If you are interested in a Hammerli 208 and the S model is too expensive or a single stage trigger is desired, I do have several 208 (non-S) available.  Price is about half that of this gun, and comparable to a better quality S&W41.
